You will need at least 1 aliquot of 70% EtOH and dH2O for each sample you want to amplify. As an example, if you aim to amplify the genome of 10 single nuclei, prepare 15 aliquots of 50 µl of 70% EtOH and 50 µl of dH2O. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cd5t4","text":"Prepare 0.2ml tubes with buffer depending on the downstream single cell Whole Genome Amplification (scWGA) method: (estimate double the number of tubes than the single nuclei to be collected):","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ebgv5","text":"           a. The number of nuclei seeded on the array is a key factor, as too many will lead to few CellRafts with single nuclei, while too little will lead to most of the CellRafts being empty, according to a Poisson distribution. Thus, seeding the array with a nuclei: wells ratio 1:2 or 1:3 increases the proportion of wells capturing a single nucleus versus wells capturing none or \u003e2 nuclei.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

The number of nuclei seeded on the array is a key factor, as too many will lead to few CellRafts with single nuclei, while too little will lead to most of the CellRafts being empty, according to a Poisson distribution. The number of nuclei seeded on the array is a key factor, as too many will lead to few CellRafts with single nuclei, while too little will lead to most of the CellRafts being empty, according to a Poisson distribution. Thus, seeding the array with a nuclei: wells ratio 1:2 or 1:3 increases the proportion of wells capturing a single nucleus versus wells capturing none or \u003e2 nuclei.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}
